title: Uniforms
intro: What's the fascination we seem to have for uniforms? Is there something about taking on a persona or professional role that can be liberating? Neil and Tim talk about the uniforms they'd like to wear and teach you six items of vocabulary.
this_week_question: In the 19th century, police officer’s top hats could be used…
c) to protect their heads from the sun?
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: it’s noticeable or easy to see
belong to a particular group and are accepted by them
the character you present to the outside world – as opposed to the person you feel like inside
feeling you can behave however you like

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Welcome to 6 Minute English, where we introduce a colourful topic and six suitable items of vocabulary.

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: I’m Tim…

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And I’m Neil. Why are you wearing a policeman’s hat, Tim?

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: To get me in the mood for our topic today – uniforms!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, the hat certainly suits you!

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: And if something suits you it looks good on you! Well, thanks, Neil. And funnily enough, I have a question for you on the subject of police hats! In the 19th century, police officers' top hats could be used… a) to stand on, b) as a weapon or c) to protect their heads from the sun?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, they're kind of pointy so I’m going to say as a weapon.

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: OK. Let’s consider what the point of a uniform is. Why do some jobs have them while others don’t?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well – The police, and other emergency services, like the fire brigade, and ambulance service – they need practical clothes to help them do their job.

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: People need to recognize them too, don’t they?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yeah, that’s right. A uniform makes people stand out from crowd.

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: If something stands out it’s noticeable or easy to see.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: But uniform also allows you to fit in – it shows you belong to a particular group or organization – and people often enjoy that sense of community at work.

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: Do you think we should get some 6 Minute English T-shirts made, Neil?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, we share a sense of community without team T-shirts, Tim. Let’s listen to cultural historian, Joe Moran, talking about why wearing a uniform can also allow you to behave differently to the way you normally behave.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Joe Moran, cultural historian It’s a role and a genre that you adopt and it’s kind of – it’s something that’s not quite you. It’s kind of a persona that you can put on. In Germany they call it ‘maskenfreiheit’, which is the freedom conferred by masks. There’s something about taking on what is very clearly a persona or professional role, that can be liberating, I think.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So when you put on a uniform you are adopting a role or genre. Genre means a particular style. And a persona is a character you present to the outside world – as opposed to the person you feel like inside.

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: Joe Moran compares putting on a persona to putting on a mask. And he says this can be very liberating . But do you really think putting on a uniform liberates – or frees – us from the person we really are?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Maybe. If you’re shy, for example, a uniform might feel liberating because it allows you to behave more confidently. So, if you could choose a uniform and a new persona, what would it be, Tim?

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: Hmm. An airline pilot, I think. I’d look great in a blazer with brass buttons – and with the cap and mirror sunglasses. Hello, this is your captain speaking. We’ll shortly be arriving at LAX airport in sunny Los Angeles. Local time is 12.55 and it’s hot hot hot outside, so I hope you’ve packed plenty of sun cream.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: OK Tim, stop, stop, stop, stop, stop! I can see you’d love being a pilot – or at least you’d love talking to your passengers!

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: What about you, Neil? What would you like to try on for size? A surgeon’s scrubs? A nun’s habit?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: To try something on for size means to decide whether it’s what you want or not. No Tim… I’d go for a chef’s apron, checked trousers, a tall hat.

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: I think the uniform would suit you, but are you good at cooking, Neil?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I’m an excellent cook. Now, I think we should have the answer to today’s quiz question, Tim.

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: Yes, I asked what a police officer’s hat could be used for in the 19th century.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And I said as a weapon.

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: Wrong, I’m afraid. From 1829 to 1839, Metropolitan Police officers wore a cane-reinforced top hat, which could be used as a step to climb or see over walls. I wonder if modern police hats are strong enough to stand on?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: We’ll try yours later and find out. But now let’s go over the other key words we learned today.

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: OK. If something ‘suits you’, it looks good on you. For example, “Does this pilot’s uniform suit me, Neil?”

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: It suits you down to the ground, Tim! And that means it suits you very well!

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: Number two – If something ‘stands out’, it’s noticeable or easy to see.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: “My colourful suit really stood out at the party.”

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: In a good way, I hope! OK, next item – ‘to fit in’ – means you belong to a particular group and are accepted by them.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: “I never fitted in with the cool kids at school.”

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I’m sorry to hear that, Tim! Maybe you weren’t wearing the right uniform? Number four is ‘persona’ – the character you present to the outside world – as opposed to the person you feel like inside.

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: “My work persona is confident and chatty but I’m actually rather shy.”

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I’m learning a lot about you today, Tim!

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: They’re just examples, Neil. I don’t have a work persona – that’s the nice thing about our job – there’s no need to put on masks or personas.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Just the occasional hat…

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: Indeed. And a very nice hat this is too – I think I’ll keep it. Now, let’s finish the vocabulary! Number five – ‘liberating’ means feeling you can behave however you like.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: For example, “Talking openly about your problems can be very liberating.” Tim And finally, ‘to try something on for size’ means to test something to decide whether you want it or not.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Our listeners can try these new vocabulary items on for size and decide whether they’ll be useful or not!

transcript.author: Tim
transcript.text: And if not, then please let us know by visiting our Twitter, Facebook and YouTube pages and telling us what you think!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Goodbye! Tim Bye!
